Link

I made a number of changes to the eyes to get this to work.

Just check out the .html and .css files!






We will use our third language - JavaScript
We can use the <script> element or include a .js file.
I always start my files as:



anything_calvin_does.html

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
    <script type="text/javascript" src="script.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    ...





The most used coding language of all time.
Runs on every computer in the world that has a webbrowser.

Even if the internet is out!

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
ğŸ’¡ Idea

We will move the pupil
The pupil was position within the eye on the ghost using the left and top styles.
For example, we can move the 10vmin left and top.

This moves the â€œpupilâ€ off the â€œeyeâ€ as the â€œeyeâ€ is only â€œ6vminâ€ in radius.

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
ğŸ“ Geometry

The eye is 6x6
The pupil is 3x3
So to move the pupil all the way across the eye, move it by 3 from top and left, each.

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
ğŸ“º Display

We can follow the mouse
If the mouse is leftmost, the pupil should be at left:0vmin
If the mouse is rightmost, the pupil should be at left:3vmin
Helpfully:

JavaScript will tell us where the mouse is, and
JavaScript will let us easily update the style of an element.

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
Step 0

Letâ€™s start making eye.js
Weâ€™ll start with the â€œHello, world!â€ example.



script.js

function hello() {
    alert("Hello, world!")
}

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
ğŸ­ Scripts!
ğŸ­ Scripts!
ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
Step 3 ğŸ

We have to unwrap the event.

Lots of nonsense in there.

Letâ€™s look at just the x coordinate within the webpage

Itâ€™s called pageX

function hello(event) {
  alert(event.pageX)
}

Text

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
Alert ğŸš¨

You may notice clicking toward the left gives smaller numbers and to the right gives bigger numbers.

If you didnâ€™t try it below!

We can use these numbers to move the pupil!

Text

title: ğŸ­ Scripts!
ğŸ­ Scripts!
ğŸ­ Scripts!
text:
Step 5 ğŸ“

We wanted our maximum pupil movement to be 3
JavaScript helpful knows the maximum value for x - it is window.innerWidth

I just looked it up I never wouldâ€™ve guessed.

We divide the x value by the maximum, then multiply by 3.

function hello(event) {
    alert(3 * event.pageX / window.innerWidth)
}
Text

title: ğŸ˜ Style!
ğŸ˜ Style!
ğŸ˜ Style!
text:
Why?

What if you want:

Bold
Italic
Underline
Centered
Pink text on a green background.


<p style="font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;text-decoration:underline;text-align:center;color:pink;background:green">No problem.</p>

No problem.

title: ğŸ˜ Style!
ğŸ˜ Style!
text:
How?

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)
In your <head>, add a <style> element.
Write out all the styling you want!
Weâ€™ll show a minimal example!

title: ğŸ˜ Style!
ğŸ˜ Style!
text:
Why?

More consistent.

Can say â€œstylishâ€ anywhere!

Less messy.

Easier to e.g.Â translate â€œNo problem!â€ â‡’ â€œÂ¡No hay problema!â€

Can be placed in a separate fileâ€¦

title: ğŸ˜ Style!
text:
What?

Moving all the formatting to a header is nice enoughâ€¦
But what if we have multiple pages on our website!

â€œAbout meâ€ and â€œCool poemsâ€, perhaps.

We may want to style them both the same!

Way easier when you have multiple styles.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

Create a GitHub account!

Use whatever name and password you wantâ€¦

But make sure you remember them!

I really recommend using your .edu email address!

You get extra goodies!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

Creating an account on GitHub
Or:

Go to GitHub.com
Enter your email.
Click Sign up for GitHub
Follow the steps!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

GitHub is a great tool for:

Learning new technologies.
Sharing your projects.
Working on projects together.
Creating websites or portfolios.

I wish Iâ€™d learned about it sooner!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

Create a GitHub repository!

Repositories are how GitHub stores the information in a website
Use whatever name you wantâ€¦

But make sure you remember it!

(Someday) it will live at:

<account name>.github.io/<repository name>
Check out cd-example.github.io/bug-free-sniffle/

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

Quickstart for repositories
Or:

Go to GitHub.com

It should look different now that youâ€™re logged in!

Click  New

Give it a name
Add a README file
Click Create Repositry

text:

Store files that make up a webpage:

â€œHTMLâ€ page â€œcontentâ€.
â€œCSSâ€ page â€œformattingâ€.
â€œJSâ€ (JavaScript) â€œinteractivityâ€.

Online code editor

Google Docs for code.

Has a lot of options.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

Creating a codespace for a repository
Or:

On the page for the respository you createdâ€¦

github.com/<account name>/<repository name>

Click  <> Code ğŸ”½
Click the â€œCodespacesâ€ tab.
Click Create codespace on main
A new window will openâ€¦ slowly.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

Edit files that make up a webpages:

â€œHTMLâ€ page â€œcontentâ€.

Weâ€™ll do this one first!
It is the foundation of all webpages!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

Now: The first achievement when coding!
â€œHello, world!â€
Within GitHub codespaces, create a new file.

It must be called index.html
HTML for â€œhypertext markup languageâ€
The language of the internet!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

On the left side of the screen, ensure â€œExplorerâ€ is opened.
Two overlapping files 
A bar will pop out and at the top there will be a few icons.

Click the file with a + on it.
If missing, â€œmouseoverâ€ repository name!

Type index.html as the name and press enter.
A new file will open up, type â€œHello, world!â€

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text: ğŸ‘€ Visually

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

We want to be able to determine what appears on our webpage.
For now, it matters less what we change than that we can change the content.
Weâ€™ll learn more soon!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

We need changes made in codespaces to become changes in the repository.

You may wonder why this isnâ€™t automatic: Iâ€™m not sure!

To do so we will change from the â€œExplorerâ€ activity to the â€œSource Controlâ€ activity

Itâ€™s the technical term for â€œkeeping track of codeâ€

Lots of paperwork!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

Click the 
Click  âœ“ Commit 

I get a box pop-up and say Always

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
ğŸš¨ Alert!

This pops up :



COMMIT_EDITMSG


# Please enter the commit message for your changes. Lines starting
# with '#' will be ignored, and an empty message aborts the commit.
#
# On branch main
# Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.
#
# Changes to be committed:
#   new file:   index.html
#







Caution



We must name our changes.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
ğŸ¤ Resolve

Add any message to the first line:



COMMIT_EDITMSG

Hi it's me :)
### Please enter...


Click the âœ“ on the top right.
Click  Sync Changes 1 â†‘ 
Now go back to the repository page.

There should now be an index.html there!
You may need to refresh/reload.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

We donâ€™t want just anyone or anything publish to a website we administer.

Spam, broken links, stale memes, etc.
Mostly GitHub doesnâ€™t want that and wonâ€™t leave it up to us!

This process requires every change to be intentional.

I would rather it be easier, but thatâ€™s okay!
It gets better every year!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

Letâ€™s take index.html and make it a webpage!
Weâ€™ll use â€œGitHub Pagesâ€

Not too hard to set upâ€¦
I use it a lot for fun ğŸ˜¬

Youâ€™ll be able to show anything you do to friends and family!

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
How?

Creating a GitHub Pages site
Or:

Back on the repository pageâ€¦ - <account name>.github.io/<repository name>
Weâ€™ll change repository settings.

On the top, click on  Settings
On the left, click on  Pages
In the middle, under branch, change â€œNoneâ€ to â€œMainâ€ via the drop-down menu.

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
What?

Check our work.
Learn how to see where updates will show up.

A few minutes after â€œCommit+Syncâ€

Tell ourselves we did a good job!

text:

<account name>.github.io/<repository name>
Or:

Back to <> Code
Bottom right, under â€œDeploymentsâ€, click github-pages
There will be a link on this page under the heading github-pages

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

Thereâ€™s many ways to publish online but this isâ€¦

Free.
Relatively quick (minutes, not hours).
Powerful enough for interactive, public webpages.

It also builds a lot of valuable skills!

Learn how to see where updates will show up.

A few minutes after â€œCommit+Syncâ€

Tell ourselves we did a good job!

<account name>.github.io/<repository name>

title: ğŸ“„ Webpages!
text:
Why?

Thereâ€™s many ways to publish online but this isâ€¦

Free.
Relatively quick (minutes, not hours).
Powerful enough for interactive, public webpages.

It also builds a lot of valuable skills!

HTML Living Standard

Search (via Ctrl+f
Look for <head>
The first â€œhitâ€ will be the most basic HTML page that is well-formed

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

It is a little to easy to give up and do nothing.
That is no fun!
Check that everything works, every time.
Itâ€™s good practice!

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
What?

The part of HTML we see is the content

Usually text (like this)
Sometimes images, like below:



An image of an image of an image

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
âš ï¸ Caution

Usually nothing breaks if you omit the closing tag </p>
It is considered poor form because it can cause problems in more complicated cases.



index.html

<p>This will work but is sketchy.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

Until now, we had no way to tell HTML when to start a new line.
This looked dreadful!
Now we can!

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
ğŸ† Bonus!

You donâ€™t only have to use <p>, of course!
The next most common are headings - <h1> is the biggest.
Try giving your webpage a heading perhaps saying itâ€™s mine.



index.html

<h1>My Rad Page ğŸï¸</h1>

<p>I have interesting thoughts to share!</p>

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
What?

We can include one kind of HTML content in another kind of HTML content.
I term this â€œnestingâ€

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

This sort of nesting is a natural way to arrange information.

Letters in words.
Words in sentences.
Sentences in paragraphs.
Paragraphs in essays.
Etc.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
âš ï¸ Caution

We can nest but not overlap.
Consider the example using bold and italics
Try this:



bad

<p>This is <em>very <strong>wrong</em>!</strong></p>


This is very wrong!


And this:



good

<p>This <em>is <strong>correct</strong>.</em></p>


This is correct.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
What?

Not every part of a webpage is content.
To specify just the page content, we place it within a <body>.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
ğŸ¥· An Aside

Content is enclosed in â€œtagsâ€, like <p>
Content and tag is called an element.




Thing
Term




Hello
Content


<p>
Tag


<p>Hello</p>
Element




Most useful to look up how to do things.

E.g. center text with the <center> tag.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
How?

Weâ€™ll use a new element - <body>
Weâ€™ll buy everything so far inside it.

For me, this meant indenting everything again.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

This doesnâ€™t do anything yet.
But will allow us to add headers:

Ways to change how the page is understoodâ€¦

text:

It is probably â€œCoding Camp - ğŸŒ HTML!â€

How did that get there?

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

Less important than it used to be, though still looks sharp.
Historically important for search engines!

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
What?

In the very early days there were (maybe?) formats other than HTML.
I donâ€™t know what they would be!
But there were at least other versions (namely 1-4)
So HTML pages should specify they areâ€¦ HTML!

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

Makes things easier (and therefore faster) for web browsers.
Mark of professionalism.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
text:
What?

Sometimes we want to leave notes to ourselves or other web developers.
We donâ€™t need everyone visiting our page to see them.
We do this using the special â€œcommentâ€ element.

title: ğŸ“º Content!
ğŸ“º Content!
text:
Why?

I most usually it to keep track of notes.
Many of my pages have the following:



index.html

What?

We have now covered all the requirements to make a well-formed HTML page!

Per â€œindeed.comâ€ (maybe donâ€™t just trust them).

title: ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
What?

Yosra Emad, cool CSS artist/coder made this:

title: ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
How?

Yosra:

Creates HTML elements for each â€œpartâ€ of the art.
Uses CSS styling to change colors and borders.
We will do the same!

title: ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
Why?

Itâ€™s cute!

title: ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
What?



First, make the skeleton of the structure by looking for layers from back to front.
We notice, for example, there could be a back-most circle element forming the body.
Use the <div> element - a very general â€œdivisionâ€ of website content.

We will use no content at all - only style the <div>

title: ğŸ–¼ Art!
ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
Citation needed



Booplesnoot and other part names are a throwback to a legendary meme of a bunny.

ğŸ–¼ Art!
text:
Aside: Border Radius

We can clip the borders of elements with backgrounds to be round instead of square with a radius.




0%

<div style="background:red;border-radius:0%;text-align:center">Text</div>

Text



10%

<div style="background:red;border-radius:10%;text-align:center">Text</div>

Text



25%

<div style="background:red;border-radius:25%;text-align:center">Text</div>

Text



50%

<div style="background:red;border-radius:50%;text-align:center">Text</div>

Text
